The court has legal power to deal with this application because the following applies:
Choose one of the following reasons to support the fact that the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
Give some brief details to support the reason why the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
Include the date on which the petitioner first became aware of the adultery.

Include what the petitioner believes they know about the adultery (the adultery that forms the basis of this petition). If the petitioner doesn't know any details of the adultery, say that they are unknown and explain why.
Do not name the person with whom the adultery was committed, unless the petitioner wishes to formally include them in the divorce proceedings.
Have the petitioner and respondent lived together for more than 6 months since the adultery date?
The petitioner has the option to name the person with whom the respondent committed adultery.
Once named, they will usually become a co-respondent in the proceedings and will be sent copies of the application.
The divorce could be delayed and cost more if the co-respondent does not respond
Give some brief details to support the reason why the marriage has broken down irretrievably.

Include examples of the respondent's behaviour which affect the petitioner the most, and the most recent incidents. Try to include dates if available. If the petitioner thinks their health has been affected, state how it has been affected
Provide enough examples to satisfy the court that the petitioner cannot reasonably be expected to live with the respondent
Give some brief details to support the reason why the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
The respondent must have chosen to leave the petitioner for this reason to be valid. For example, you can't use desertion if the respondent has been sent to prison.
Have the petitioner and respondent lived apart since the date?
Give some brief details to support the reason why the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
You need to provide the following dates related to petitioner separation. The court will use the most recent separation date as the petitioner and respondent separated.
Has there been any period or periods since the separation date that the petitioner and the respondent have resumed living together as a couple?
Enter the details and dates for the period or periods
A claim for costs can include all the fees the petitioner has to pay during the divorce, such as application fees, solicitor fees and any extra court fees.
You need to upload a digital photo or scan of the marriage certificate.
You can also upload other documents that you need to send to the court, e.g.
• Certified translation of a non-English marriage certificate
The image must be of the entire document and has to be readable by court staff. You can upload jpg, bmp, png, tif, or PDF files (max file size 10MB per file)
## The petitioner is applying to the court
That the marriage be dissolved as it has broken down irretrievably.
That a costs order may be granted.
That a financial order may be granted.
I have discussed the possibility of a reconciliation with the petitioner.
I have given the petitioner the names and addresses of persons qualified to help effect a reconciliation.
You could be fined or imprisoned for contempt of court if you deliberately submit false information.
If you have any comments you would like to make to the court staff regarding the application you may include them below.

Label: Payment Method: Cheque (payable to 'HM Courts & Tribunal Service')

### Please continue to submit your application on the next screen. 
The application will be checked. If it’s correct, you’ll be sent a notice of issue. The respondent will also receive a copy of the application unless you have chosen to personally effect service.
In cases of adultery where the co-respondent was named, they will also get a copy and a form to return.
Contact the divorce centre if you don't hear anything back after 3 weeks.

Phone: 0300 303 0642 (Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5pm)
Email: EastMidlandsDivorce@Justice.gov.uk
This is a new service that is still being developed. If you haven't already done so, please provide feedback on what you think of it and how it can be improved.
You can contact the divorce centre if you need help with your application.

Phone: 0300 303 0642 (Monday to Friday, 8.30am to 5pm)
Email: EastMidlandsDivorce@Justice.gov.uk
## Write your reference number on your cheque
If you can’t write the reference number on the back, you can print this screen and include it in the envelope.
Post the cheque to the following address:
East Midlands Regional Divorce Centre, PO Box 10447, Nottingham, Nottinghamshire, NG2 9QN
Enter your reference
HintText: This will appear on your statement to help you identify this payment

Label: Do you wish to effect service on the respondent?
Divorce – *Opposite Sex Couple* – Article 3(1) of Council Regulation (EC) No 2201/2003 of 27 November 2003
Divorce – *Same Sex Couple* – Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Jurisdiction and Recognition of Judgments) Regulations 2014 for matrimonial proceedings involving same sex couples
I am duly authorised by the petitioner to sign this statement.
Usually, to be eligible for residual jurisdiction, the petitioner and/or the respondent must be domiciled in England or Wales,
and neither must be nationals of, or habitually resident in, another EU country (except Denmark).
In addition, in the case of a same-sex marriage, the petitioner may be eligible for residual jurisdiction if all the following apply:
• The petitioner and the respondent married each other in England or Wales
• Neither the petitioner nor the respondent are nationals of, or habitually resident in, another country in the EU (except Denmark)
• It would be in the interests of justice for the court to consider the application (this may apply if, for example, the petitioner's home country doesn’t allow divorce between same-sex couples)

Label: Date the petitioner and respondent started living apart
HintText: Petitioner and respondent can both live in the same property and be considered by the court to be living apart, as long as they're living separate lives. For example, they don’t eat, sleep or socialise together.

Label: Period of time petitioner and respondent can have lived together and still use the selected reason.
Have the petitioner and respondent lived together for more than ${D8SeparationTimeTogetherPermitted} since ${D8SeparationReferenceDate} ?

If the petitioner and respondent lived together for more than ${D8SeparationTimeTogetherPermitted} since ${D8SeparationReferenceDate} they won't have been separated for long enough to use the ${SepYears} years separation reason for divorce at this time.

If the petitioner and respondent lived together for more than ${D8DesertionTimeTogetherPermitted} since ${D8SeparationReferenceDate} they won't have been separated for long enough to use desertion as  reason for divorce at this time.

### The petitioner must find it intolerable to live with the respondent

The petitioner must find it intolerable (unbearable) to live with the respondent if they want to use adultery as the reason for divorce. This applies whether they are still living together or not. If the petitioner does not find it intolerable, they will need to pay a £95 fee to change the application and use another reason for divorce. The application will also need to be sent to the respondent again.
Contact the Courts and Tribunals Service Centre to change your application, or go back to change your answer.
